title: Sports in Vancouver
text:
There have been a wide variety of sports in Vancouver since the city was founded. Team sports such as <a href="ice%20hockey">ice hockey</a>, <a href="lacrosse">lacrosse</a>, and <a href="Canadian%20football">Canadian football</a> have extensive history in the area, while the city's relatively mild climate and geographical location facilitate a wide variety of other sports and recreational activities.
Sports teams.
A number of amateur and professional sports teams are based in Vancouver.
Amateur.
The <a href="Vancouver%20Giants">Vancouver Giants</a> of the <a href="Western%20Hockey%20League">Western Hockey League</a>, founded in <a href="2001%E2%80%9302%20WHL%20season">2001</a>, play their home games in Langley. The Giants hosted and won the <a href="2007%20Memorial%20Cup">2007 Memorial Cup</a>. The Vancouver area also has a number of hockey teams in the Tier II <a href="British%20Columbia%20Hockey%20League">British Columbia Hockey League</a>.
There are a number of amateur <a href="lacrosse">lacrosse</a> teams in <a href="Greater%20Vancouver">Greater Vancouver</a>, competing under the auspices of the <a href="British%20Columbia%20Lacrosse%20Association">British Columbia Lacrosse Association</a>. The <a href="New%20Westminster%20Salmonbellies">New Westminster Salmonbellies</a> have won the <a href="Mann%20Cup">Mann Cup</a>, Canada's senior lacrosse championship, a record 24 times. There are also several amateur teams in sports such as <a href="soccer">soccer</a>, <a href="baseball">baseball</a>, <a href="softball">softball</a>, <a href="Canadian%20football">Canadian football</a>, <a href="field%20hockey">field hockey</a>, <a href="rugby%20football">rugby</a>, <a href="Gaelic%20football">Gaelic football</a>, <a href="Water%20Polo">Water Polo</a>, <a href="Ultimate%20Canada">disc ultimate</a> and <a href="roller%20derby">roller derby</a>.
Prominent annual amateur sports events in Vancouver include the BC High School Basketball Championship at the <a href="PNE%20Agrodome">PNE Agrodome</a>, the High School Football Championship at <a href="BC%20Place">BC Place</a>, and the <a href="Canada%20Cup%20%28softball%29">Canada Cup</a> softball tournament in <a href="South%20Surrey">South Surrey</a>. Also notable is the college rivalry between the <a href="UBC%20Thunderbirds">UBC Thunderbirds</a> and <a href="Simon%20Fraser%20Clan">Simon Fraser Clan</a>, who meet annually in the <a href="Shrum%20Bowl">Shrum Bowl</a> (football) and Buchanan Cup (basketball). These are very popular sport events in Vancouver.
Professional.
Vancouver is home to a number of professional sports teams, including a number of teams in <a href="major%20professional%20sports%20leagues%20in%20the%20United%20States%20and%20Canada">major professional sports leagues of North America</a>, including the <a href="Canadian%20Football%20League">Canadian Football League</a>, <a href="Major%20League%20Soccer">Major League Soccer</a>, and the <a href="National%20Hockey%20League">National Hockey League</a>.
BC Lions.
The British Columbia (BC) Lions have played in the Canadian Football League since <a href="1954%20in%20Canadian%20football">1954</a>, and have won the <a href="Grey%20Cup">Grey Cup</a> six times, in <a href="1964%20Grey%20Cup">1964</a>, <a href="1985%20Grey%20Cup">1985</a>, <a href="1994%20Grey%20Cup">1994</a>, <a href="2000%20Grey%20Cup">2000</a>, <a href="2006%20Grey%20Cup">2006</a> and in 2011. Vancouver has hosted the Grey Cup championship fourteen times, most recently in <a href="2011%20Grey%20Cup">2011</a>. The Lions play their home games at <a href="BC%20Place%20Stadium">BC Place Stadium</a> in downtown Vancouver, having previously played at <a href="Empire%20Stadium%20%28Vancouver%29">Empire Stadium</a> in East Vancouver until the end of the 1982 season.
Vancouver Canadians.
The Vancouver Canadians play in the High-A West of the <a href="Minor%20League%20Baseball">Minor League Baseball</a> (MiBL). The Canadians play their home games at <a href="Scotiabank%20Field%20at%20Nat%20Bailey%20Stadium">Scotiabank Field at Nat Bailey Stadium</a> and are affiliated with the <a href="Toronto%20Blue%20Jays">Toronto Blue Jays</a> of <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a>. <a href="Minor%20league%20baseball">Minor league baseball</a> has a long history in Vancouver, including the <a href="Vancouver%20Beavers">Vancouver Beavers</a>, the <a href="Vancouver%20Capilanos">Vancouver Capilanos</a>, an earlier incarnation of the Canadians and the <a href="Vancouver%20Mounties">Vancouver Mounties</a>; both the latter two played in the Class AAA <a href="Pacific%20Coast%20League">Pacific Coast League</a>. Vancouver continues to have a huge interest in acquiring a full-time <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> team and having them play their home games at <a href="BC%20Place%20Stadium">BC Place Stadium</a> in downtown Vancouver.
Vancouver Canucks.
The Vancouver Canucks have played in the <a href="National%20Hockey%20League">National Hockey League</a> since <a href="1970%E2%80%9371%20NHL%20season">1970</a>, and have reached the <a href="Stanley%20Cup">Stanley Cup</a> finals three times, in <a href="1981%E2%80%9382%20NHL%20season">1982</a>, <a href="1993%E2%80%9394%20NHL%20season">1994</a> (the Canucks' 1994 run was unfortunately marred by the <a href="1994%20Stanley%20Cup%20riot">1994 Stanley Cup riot</a>) and <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20NHL%20season">2011</a> (which again incited the <a href="2011%20Stanley%20Cup%20riot">2011 Stanley Cup riot</a> after the Canucks' loss to Boston). The Canucks play their home games at <a href="Rogers%20Arena">Rogers Arena</a>, having previously played at the <a href="Pacific%20Coliseum">Pacific Coliseum</a> until 1995. Previous incarnations of the Canucks played in the <a href="Pacific%20Coast%20Hockey%20League">Pacific Coast Hockey League</a> and <a href="Western%20Hockey%20League%20%28minor%20pro%29">Western Hockey League</a> and won multiple championships. The <a href="Vancouver%20Blazers">Vancouver Blazers</a>, a <a href="World%20Hockey%20Association">World Hockey Association</a> team, attempted to compete with the Canucks between 1973 and 1975, but moved to Calgary thereafter. An early professional hockey team known as the <a href="Vancouver%20Millionaires">Vancouver Millionaires</a> won the Stanley Cup in 1915.
Vancouver Titans.
The Vancouver Titans have played in the <a href="Overwatch%20League">Overwatch League</a> since 2019 and was one of the first expansion teams in the league.
Vancouver Warriors.
The Vancouver Warriors are a <a href="box%20lacrosse">box lacrosse</a> team in the <a href="National%20Lacrosse%20League">National Lacrosse League</a>. The team moved from Everett, Washington for the <a href="2014%20NLL%20season">2014 NLL season</a>. Between 2014 and 2017, the team (then known as the Vancouver Stealth) were based in the <a href="Vancouver">Vancouver</a> suburb of <a href="Langley%2C%20British%20Columbia%20%28district%20municipality%29">Langley, British Columbia</a>, with home games played at the <a href="Langley%20Events%20Centre">Langley Events Centre</a> (LEC). In 2018, the team was purchased by <a href="Canucks%20Sports%20%26amp%3B%20Entertainment">Canucks Sports & Entertainment</a>, who relocated the team to <a href="Rogers%20Place">Rogers Place</a> in Vancouver, and announced that they would be rebranding the team as the Vancouver Warriors for the 2018-19 season.
Vancouver Whitecaps FC.
In the 2011 season, the Vancouver Whitecaps FC joined <a href="Major%20League%20Soccer">Major League Soccer</a>. The squad plays their home games in a renovated <a href="BC%20Place%20Stadium">BC Place Stadium</a>.
Vancouver Knights.
The Vancouver Knights were one of the inaugural teams in the <a href="Global%20T20%20Canada">Global T20 Canada</a> <a href="Twenty20">Twenty20</a> <a href="cricket">cricket</a> tournament. The team does not have a designated home venue, playing all their matches at <a href="Brampton">Brampton</a>, <a href="Ontario">Ontario</a>. They were the <a href="2018%20Global%20T20%20Canada">inaugural</a> champions, having won in 2018.
Former teams.
The expansion <a href="Vancouver%20Grizzlies">Vancouver Grizzlies</a> of the <a href="National%20Basketball%20Association">National Basketball Association</a> were one of the anchor tenants of <a href="GM%20Place">GM Place</a> upon its completion in 1995, but moved to <a href="Memphis%2C%20Tennessee">Memphis, Tennessee</a> after just six years of operations in Vancouver. Professional basketball has been rumoured to return to Vancouver, most recently in the form of the <a href="Vancouver%20Dragons">Vancouver Dragons</a> of the <a href="Continental%20Basketball%20Association">Continental Basketball Association</a>, but has yet to establish itself. Vancouver continues to have a huge interest in acquiring a full-time <a href="National%20Basketball%20Association">National Basketball Association</a> team and having them play their home games at <a href="Rogers%20Arena">Rogers Arena</a>. Vancouver has also had professional <a href="lacrosse">lacrosse</a> (<a href="Vancouver%20Ravens">Vancouver Ravens</a>, <a href="National%20Lacrosse%20League">National Lacrosse League</a>, 2001-2004) and <a href="roller%20hockey">roller hockey</a> (<a href="Vancouver%20Voodoo">Vancouver Voodoo</a>, <a href="Roller%20Hockey%20International">Roller Hockey International</a>, 1993-1996) teams. The <a href="Vancouver%20Blazers">Vancouver Blazers</a> of the <a href="World%20Hockey%20Association">World Hockey Association</a> played in the <a href="Pacific%20Coliseum">Pacific Coliseum</a> for two seasons (1973/74 and 1974/75).
The <a href="Vancouver%20Royal%20Canadians">Vancouver Royal Canadians</a> were an <a href="association%20football">association football</a> team based in <a href="Vancouver">Vancouver</a>, <a href="British%20Columbia">British Columbia</a>, Canada that played in the <a href="United%20Soccer%20Association">United Soccer Association</a>. The league was made up of teams imported almost entirely from Scotland and England. The Vancouver club was actually <a href="Sunderland%20A.F.C.">Sunderland A.F.C.</a> of <a href="Football%20League">English Football League</a>.
Following the 1967 season, the USA merged with the <a href="National%20Professional%20Soccer%20League%20%281967%29">National Professional Soccer League</a> to form the <a href="North%20American%20Soccer%20League%20%281968%E2%80%931984%29">North American Soccer League</a> with the teams from the former USA having to create their rosters from scratch. The <a href="San%20Francisco%20Golden%20Gate%20Gales">San Francisco Golden Gate Gales</a> franchise folded and their owners bought a controlling interest in the Royal Canadians renaming them the Vancouver Royals. Their home field was <a href="Empire%20Stadium%2C%20Vancouver">Empire Stadium</a>.
The <a href="Vancouver%20Nighthalks">Vancouver Nighthalks</a> were a semi-professional ultimate team that competed in the <a href="Major%20League%20Ultimate">Major League Ultimate</a> association. They played home games at the <a href="Thunderbird%20Stadium">Thunderbird Stadium</a> at <a href="University%20of%20British%20Columbia">University of British Columbia</a> until 2016 where they had suspended play after the MLU was suspended.
The <a href="Vancouver%20Riptide">Vancouver Riptide</a> played in the <a href="American%20Ultimate%20Disc%20League">American Ultimate Disc League</a> from 2013 to 2017 playing home games at the Burnaby <a href="Swangard%20Stadium">Swangard Stadium</a>. They folded after the <a href="2017%20AUDL%20Season">2017 AUDL Season</a> due to a lack of attendance and sponsorship and are moving down to Portland for the 2020 season.
Sporting events.
The Vancouver area has also hosted multiple <a href="BC%20Games">BC Games</a> amateur sports events. The <a href="Slam%20City%20Jam">Slam City Jam</a> skateboarding championship was held in Vancouver from 1994 to 2005, and was set to return in 2008. Upcoming events include the 2008 <a href="http%3A//www.wugc2008.com">World Ultimate and Guts Championship</a> and the 2009 <a href="World%20Police%20and%20Fire%20Games">World Police and Fire Games</a>.
Annual events include the <a href="Vancouver%20Marathon">Vancouver Marathon</a> (42K/21K), the <a href="Vancouver%20Sun%20Run">Vancouver Sun Run</a> (a 10 km race), Scotiabank Vancouver Half-Marathon and the <a href="Cloverdale%20Rodeo%20and%20Country%20Fair">Cloverdale Rodeo</a>. The <a href="British%20Columbia%20Derby">British Columbia Derby</a> is a nine furlong horse race held at the Hastings Racecourse in the third week of September. Former annual events include the <a href="Molson%20Indy%20Vancouver">Molson Indy Vancouver</a>, a <a href="Champ%20Car">Champ Car</a> race held from 1990 to 2004; and the <a href="Greater%20Vancouver%20Institutional">Greater Vancouver Institutional</a>, a golf tournament held from 1996 to 2010. The <a href="Canadian%20Open%20%28golf%29">Canadian Open</a>, a golf tournament which alternates venues annually, was last held in Vancouver in 2011.
The <a href="2010%20Winter%20Olympics">2010 Winter Olympics</a> and <a href="2010%20Winter%20Paralympics">Paralympics</a> took place in Vancouver, and was organized by what was called VANOC (Vancouver Organizing Committee for the 2010 Olympic and Paralympic Winter Games). The 2010 Winter Olympics was the third Olympics hosted by Canada, and the first by the province of British Columbia. In the 2010 Winter Olympics, the mascots were Miga, a mythical sea bear, part orca and part kermode bear, Quatchi, a sasquatch, and Sumi, an animal guardian spirit with the wings of the Thunderbird and legs of a black bear. Miga and Quatchi were the mascots for the Olympics while Sumi was the mascot for the Paralympics.
Other past sports events hosted in Vancouver include:
Facilities.
Major sports facilities in Vancouver are <a href="Rogers%20Arena">Rogers Arena</a> (a.k.a. <a href="GM%20Place">GM Place</a>, <a href="Canada%20Hockey%20Place">Canada Hockey Place</a>), <a href="BC%20Place">BC Place</a>, the <a href="Pacific%20Coliseum">Pacific Coliseum</a>, the <a href="PNE%20Agrodome">PNE Agrodome</a> and <a href="Nat%20Bailey%20Stadium">Nat Bailey Stadium</a>. BC Place is also home to the <a href="BC%20Sports%20Hall%20of%20Fame">BC Sports Hall of Fame</a>, founded in 1966. There are many other facilities throughout the city and surrounding area, including 8 Rinks in <a href="Burnaby">Burnaby</a>, the Canucks' main practice venue.
The relatively mild climate of Vancouver, its extensive parkland, and close proximity to ocean, mountains, rivers and lakes provides it with a number of areas for outdoor sporting activities, both competitive and recreational. The area is a popular destination for outdoor sports and recreation, including on and <a href="Offroad%20cycling">off-road</a> <a href="cycling">cycling</a>, <a href="skateboarding">skateboarding</a>, <a href="hiking">hiking</a>, <a href="alpine%20skiing">alpine</a> and <a href="cross-country%20skiing">cross-country skiing</a>, <a href="snowboarding">snowboarding</a>, <a href="Flying%20disc%20games">disc sports</a>, <a href="golf">golf</a>, and <a href="water%20sport%20%28recreation%29">water sports</a>. The nearby <a href="North%20Shore%20Mountains">North Shore Mountains</a> are home to three ski hills, <a href="Cypress%20Mountain">Cypress Mountain</a>, <a href="Grouse%20Mountain">Grouse Mountain</a>, and <a href="Mount%20Seymour">Mount Seymour</a>; each are within 20 to 30 minutes (driving time) of downtown Vancouver.
Media.
Vancouver's major daily newspapers, the <a href="Vancouver%20Sun">Vancouver Sun</a> and <a href="Vancouver%20Province">Vancouver Province</a>, provide extensive coverage of local sports. <a href="CKNW%20%28AM%29">CKNW</a> was historically the main radio broadcaster of Vancouver's sports teams, but <a href="CKST%20%28AM%29">CKST</a>, an <a href="sports%20radio">all-sports</a> station founded in 2001, broadcasts the Canucks, Lions, Whitecaps and Canadians . On television, most events are carried by <a href="Rogers%20Sportsnet">Sportsnet Pacific</a>, <a href="The%20Sports%20Network">TSN</a>, <a href="CBC%20Television">CBC</a>, or <a href="Shaw%20TV">Shaw TV</a>.
Famous athletes.
The Vancouver area has produced a number of notable athletes, including <a href="Cam%20Neely">Cam Neely</a> (born in Comox, raised in Lower Mainland), <a href="Joe%20Sakic">Joe Sakic</a>, <a href="Cliff%20Ronning">Cliff Ronning</a>, <a href="Milan%20Lucic">Milan Lucic</a>, <a href="Mathew%20Barzal">Mathew Barzal</a>, <a href="Ryan%20Nugent-Hopkins">Ryan Nugent-Hopkins</a>, <a href="Morgan%20Rielly">Morgan Rielly</a>, <a href="Carey%20Price">Carey Price</a>, <a href="Martin%20Jones%20%28ice%20hockey%29">Martin Jones</a>, <a href="Brent%20Seabrook">Brent Seabrook</a>, <a href="Ryan%20Johansen">Ryan Johansen</a> and <a href="Paul%20Kariya">Paul Kariya</a> (hockey); <a href="Larry%20Walker">Larry Walker</a>, <a href="Justin%20Morneau">Justin Morneau</a>, <a href="Jeff%20Francis">Jeff Francis</a>, and <a href="Adam%20Loewen">Adam Loewen</a> (baseball); <a href="Bob%20Lenarduzzi">Bob Lenarduzzi</a>, <a href="Domenic%20Mobilio">Domenic Mobilio</a>, <a href="Emilio%20Reuben">Emilio Reuben</a>, <a href="Brian%20Budd">Brian Budd</a> (born in Toronto, raised in Vancouver) and <a href="Christine%20Sinclair">Christine Sinclair</a> (soccer); <a href="Lui%20Passaglia">Lui Passaglia</a>, <a href="Paris%20Jackson%20%28footballer%29">Paris Jackson</a> and <a href="Adam%20Braidwood">Adam Braidwood</a> (football); <a href="Harry%20Jerome">Harry Jerome</a>, <a href="Charmaine%20Crooks">Charmaine Crooks</a>, <a href="Percy%20Williams%20%28sprinter%29">Percy Williams</a> (Track & Field).
